reviewText: I love train movies, and this one didn't disappoint me. While it did "drag" a little, it was able to hold my attention for more than half a dozen viewings so far.
Title: End of the Line

reviewText: I saw this movie several years ago and could not get it out of my mind. When I saw it here on Amazon, I could not wait to get it. This is just a good movie about people who are not afraid to try and do something even though they are pretty sure that there is nothing they will be able to accomplish. This is a movie that is very believable. I could actually see someone doing this if they were about to lose their jobs. This movie is well worth watching.
Title: End of the Line

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed the movie. It was a good downhome story with a very good story line. People today can relate to it with so much job loss.
Title: End of the Line

reviewText: People in a small town lose their Jobs,what is the Leftwinger's and Anarchist's Solution? Shut 'Em Down of Course!If you condone Terrorism and Hijackings then this is the movie for you! I guess the Film makers wanted to Show "The Man" funny they become The Man as most leftists do anyhow, A snore of a movie,slow acting with that guy from the Diabetes commercials and Kevin Bacon. Only thing cool is the Locomotive itself, other than That it's typical "The Man" is bad Hogwash. Long Live Corporatism!
Title: End of the Line

reviewText: I believe Wilford Brimley is a great actor because he seems to just be himself.  He plays a brakeman on the "Southland Railroad".  The railroad is being reorganized and the small town he lives in will be devastated so some rich folks in Chicago can roll in more "dough". He and another worker take a locomotive to Chicago to try and convince the "powers that be" to think twice about the reorganization. Instead the company clones try to use them in an advertising campaign to make the changes go smoother.  Brimley won't have it.  You watch the rest.  You have the sad and inevitable conflict of young and old, rich and poor played out in the heartland.  Great film.
summary: Left behind by business (ie. the rich get richer).
Title: End of the Line

reviewText: This movie was in some ways good to experience the despair of the railroad people who find themselves without hope after their jobs were eliminated.  However the era is wrong for me it should be set in the depression era not in the 2000 nd.  Some things are to far fiction for me and some of the people made up in this movie would never lasted on a railroad in real.  It was in all a good story and if you like movies that make big business the bad, mean heartless Villon then this is for you.
summary: Train movie with a human side
Title: End of the Line

reviewText: A tale of corporate greed; management wanting to make money at the expense of the "little people" and the resulting reaction of those "little people".  Somewhat like "David vs. Goliath", played out on a battlefield 4 feet, 8 1/2 inches wide.Written with a slight bias -- having been involved with being around railroading [and being a railfan] for over 50 years.
Title: End of the Line
